newsitem.title: UK: UK farmers said threatening rare bird in Hungary.
newsitem.headline: UK farmers said threatening rare bird in Hungary.

text.p: British farmers on the steppes of eastern Hungary are threatening one of the region's rarest birds, the great bustard, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB) said on Thursday.
British farmers and investors have bought land in the region, hoping it will increase in value if and when Hungary joins the European Union, the RSPB said.
But the society claimed intensive farming methods were threatening the great bustard's habitat.
Some 300 hectares (750 acres) of land have been destroyed by ploughing and another 180 hectares (450 acres) through direct drilling with maize, the RSPB said.
"If this kind of trend were to continue and the habitat destroyed, a substantial part of the European population could be lost," said RSPB spokesman Mike Everett.
The Hungarian steppes hold one of Europe's largest populations of great bustards -- 1,000 to 1,200 birds -- with some 140 to 150 in the Bihar region, the RSPB said.
The great bustard is a wary, turkey-sized bird that lives in open grasslands. It is one of 23 globally-threatened species in Europe.
